title-group.article-title: Relationship between microstructure and properties of false-twist textured and stabilized polylactide. Part 2. physicochemical characterization, accessibility of the amorphous phase and dyeing behavior

article-meta.aff: 1INTEXTER – Universitat Politècnica de Catalunya, Terrassa, Spain

author-notes.corresp: Diana Cayuela, INTEXTER – Universitat Politècnica de Catalunya, C/ Colom 15, Terrassa, 08222, Spain. Email: cayuela@intexter.upc.edu

permissions.copyright-statement: © The Author(s) 2013 Reprints and permissions: sagepub.co.uk/journalsPermissions.nav

abstract.p: Polylactide fibers (PLA), textured by false twist at different temperatures (135, 150 and 165℃) and draw ratios (1.30, 1.35 and 1.40) were stabilized by the application of a continuous thermal treatment at 100℃ and 50 m/min. The effect of thermal stabilization on the microstructure was determined by physicochemical tests such as iodine sorption or differential solubility. Iodine sorption and differential solubility are closely related to the crystallinity of the samples. Stabilization enhances crystallinity and orientation with the result that differences between the samples are diminished. Color value differences, albeit reduced, in some cases exceed the accepted limits. Color absorption is mainly dependent on the orientation and accessibility of the amorphous phase.

body.p: A polylactide (PLA) multifilament yarn, false-twist textured under different conditions, was thermally stabilized in order to improve the dimensional stability for subsequent thermal or hydrothermal treatments.1 The authors studied the effect of heat setting on the dimensional, mechanical and microstructural properties of the textured substrates.2,3

PLA processing involves thermal and/or hydrothermal treatments that enhance crystallinity and, if stress is involved, orientation. Crystallinity and orientation are the main parameters that globally define fiber microstructure. They exert considerable influence on the dimensional, mechanical and dyeing behavior of PLA as well as on its final application.

Crystallinity of PLA fibers can be determined by differential scanning calorimetry (DSC) or X-ray diffraction. There are other, simpler and cost effective techniques to evaluate crystallinity, such as density or infrared (IR) spectroscopy but they are not easily applicable to PLA. Most of the organic solvents or mixtures used for density determination plasticize PLA and invalidate the result. When inorganic dissolutions are used, it is difficult to ensure the total removal of air trapped on the surface and in the fiber, which could mask the precise determination of density. With regards to IR spectroscopy, small differences in the crystallinity of the substrates can be masked by the size of the experimental error inherent in crystallinity determination. Orientation can be determined by the sound velocity along the axis of the fiber or by birefringence.

Other physicochemical tests are related to the ability of the substrates to absorb foreign particles such as the iodine sorption test or to the swelling or solubility behavior in a solvent/non-solvent mixture, such as the differential solubility test. These tests enabled us to detect small differences in the microstructure of manmade fibers induced by textile processing. The results of the two tests (iodine sorption and differential solubility) depend on fiber compactness and are strongly linked to crystallinity and/or orientation of the fiber.

Besides crystallinity and orientation, the chain mobility of the amorphous phase that can be measured by the glass transition temperature is considerably influenced by small variations in the manufacturing or processing conditions. Chain mobility of the amorphous phase affects fiber compactness and accessibility to solvents that can be evaluated by physicochemical tests. The thermal, thermomechanical or hydrothermal histories of fibers are reflected in their ability to absorb iodine particles or to swell or dissolve in a solvent/non-solvent mixture. Generally, when the thermal treatment is stronger, the fiber compactness is higher and, consequently, the iodine sorption and the differential solubility are lower.

Changes in microstructure induced by different variables of the textile processing have been highlighted by iodine sorption or differential solubility in polyester,4–7 polyamide8,9 and textured polylactide fibers.10

The aim of this work is to study the relationship between iodine sorption, differential solubility, crystallinity, orientation, accessibility of the amorphous phase and dyeing behavior of thermally stabilized false-twist textured PLA filaments.

sec.title: Material
sec.p:
Polylactide textured filament yarns supplied by Anglés Textil S.A. were used. The initial polymer is polylactide for fiber grades with a melting point of 165–170℃ (1.4/98.6 l-/d-lactide). The 167 dtex/68 partially oriented filament yarn (POY) obtained by melting extrusion was textured at different temperatures (135, 150 and 165℃) and subjected to different draw ratios (1.30, 1.35 and 1.40). A total of eight textured yarn samples were obtained in accordance with an experimental plan. Table 1 indicates the sample references as a function of the texturing temperature and the draw ratio that was applied. Table 1.
Temperature and draw ratio conditions for the texturing process
Ref Draw ratio Texturing temperature (℃)
A1 1.30 135
A2 1.30 150
A3 1.30 165
B1 1.35 135
B2 1.35 150
B3 1.35 165
C1 1.40 135
C2 1.40 150

sec.title: Stabilization treatment
sec.p: Textured yarn samples were thermally stabilized in a prototype for continuous setting at 100℃ at a speed of 50 m/min applying a draw ratio of 1:1.07.

sec.title: DSC
sec.p: Crystallinity was obtained from DSC analysis. Thermograms were obtained in the following operating conditions: initial temperature = 50℃, final temperature = 250℃, heating rate = 20℃/min and nitrogen purging gas = 35 mL/min. Using the melting enthalpy of the sample ΔHm (J/g) and the melting enthalpy of a 100% crystalline polylactide (93.6 J/g), the percentage of crystallinity was calculated through the following relationship11,12 (1)crystallinity (%)=ΔHm93.6100 It has been demonstrated that, if the appropriate methodology is used, crystallinity measured by DSC shows a very high correlation with that measured by X-ray diffraction.10

sec.title: Orientation
sec.p: When the macromolecules in a high polymer sample (fiber or film strip) are oriented by stretching, the sound velocity along the direction of stretch increases progressively with orientation.13 Measurement of sonic velocity through the time elapsed between the application of a sonic pulse and its reception at a given distance enabled us to assess variations in the macromolecular orientation of a fiber or a film. When the sonic velocity is higher, the orientation is higher.9 Sonic velocity was determined by using the Dynamic Tester PPM-SR (H. M. Morgan Co, Inc).

sec.title: Iodine sorption
sec.p: The iodine sorption is defined as the milligrams of iodine per gram of sample sorbed by the sample after being in contact with iodine dissolution at a given temperature for twenty minutes. After the optimization of the test, the optimal composition of the iodine dissolution for polylactide fibers is 127 g I2, 200 g KI, 100 ml acetic acid and 7 ml phenol 90% per liter. The determination of the iodine sorbed by the fiber is made by titration of the sample with sodium thiosulphate after dissolution of the fiber with 65/35 phenol/2-isopropanol.10

sec.title: Differential solubility
sec.p: The differential solubility of PLA was determined as the percentage of fiber dissolved in a 50/50 phenol/2-isopropanol (w/w) mixture that was in contact with it at different temperatures for thirty minutes.10

sec.title: Thermomechanical analysis
sec.p: The chain mobility of the amorphous phase was determined by the glass transition temperature of the polymer through thermomechanical analysis. Two samples 12.8 mm in length of each reference (see Table 1) were tested in a TMA/SDTA 840 Mettler Toledo apparatus under the following conditions: initial temperature = 25℃, final temperature = 165℃, heating rate = 10℃/min and nitrogen purging gas = 35 mL/min under a periodic load between 0.025 and 0.05 N at 1/12 Hz. By analyzing the E-storage and E-loss curves, the temperature of maximum phase lag, i.e. Tϕ, between them was determined. Tϕ can be considered the glass transition temperature of the filament at which the chain mobility of the amorphous phase attains its maximum enabling an internal reordering of the macromolecules. When Tϕ is higher, the accessibility of the amorphous phase is lower and, consequently, the penetration of the iodine sorption and the solvent/non-solvent mixture to determine the differential solubility of the filament is more difficult.14

sec.title: Dyeing
sec.p: Single jersey knitted fabrics were produced under standard conditions, and were washed to remove impurities from the spinning and knitting with 1 g/L of nonionic detergent at pH 6, at 30℃ for 30 minutes before the dyeing process.

sec.title: Crystallinity, orientation and dyeing behavior
sec.p:
Table 2 includes crystallinity measured by DSC XDSC, sonic velocity SV, and maximum phase lag temperature Tϕ given by the thermomechanical analysis (TMA) of the stabilized substrates. The mean value, standard deviation (SD) and coefficient of variation (CV) are included. Table 2.
Values of crystallinity, sonic velocity and maximum phase lag temperature of stabilized PLA samples
Ref Crystallinity (%) Sonic velocity (km/s) Tϕ (℃)
A1 49.8 2.28 71.0
A2 51.4 2.36 72.3
A3 51.1 2.27 71.7
B1 52.6 2.34 72.2
B2 52.7 2.45 72.8
B3 51.7 2.31 72.1
C1 48.4 2.39 72.7
C2 50.7 2.36 72.9
Mean 51.1 2.35 72.2
SD ±1.4 ±0.06 ±0.6
CV (%) 2.8 2.5 0.9

Mean values of crystallinity, orientation and maximum phase lag temperature of the original false-twist textured PLA filaments1 were 28.6 ± 3.0% (CV = 10.5%), 1.74 ± 0.13 km/s (CV = 7.37%) and 68.4 ± 0.51℃ (CV = 0.74%) respectively, which means that crystallinity, orientation and maximum phase lag temperature were significantly increased by stabilization. With regards to the coefficients of variation, it seems that stabilization considerably reduces the existing differences in crystallinity and orientation among the samples, making them more homogeneous.

Statistical analysis of crystallinity XDS, orientation SV and maximum phase lag temperature Tϕ points out that stabilization significantly increases all these parameters. With regards to the variability induced by the different texturing conditions, stabilization significantly decreases that of the crystallinity and orientation SV while that of the maximum phase lag temperature Tϕ remains the same after stabilization. After stabilization differences in crystallinity XDSC and orientation SV between the filaments were reduced making them more homogeneous.

To determine whether these small differences in crystallinity, orientation and maximum phase lag temperature are significant from a practical point of view, a competitive dyeing of all stabilized samples was carried out. The references of single jersey fabrics made up of the stabilized false-twist textured filaments were the same as those of the filaments. The exhaustion of the dye bath was 100%. Consequently, differences in dye absorption between samples should be attributed to a distinct dyeing behavior of the stabilized samples. Accurate control of the variables of the process was carried out to avoid hydrolysis of the polylactide.15–17

Chromatic coordinates of the dyed substrates are shown in Table 3. The lightness of the stabilized filaments increases with draw ratio and texturing temperature. When the texturing intensity of the original filaments is higher, the dye absorption of the stabilized samples is lower. Lightness L as a function of draw ratio DR and texturing temperature T of the stabilized filaments is depicted in Figure 1. Figure 1.
Response surface of lightness as a function of draw ratio and texturing temperature.
Table 3.
Chromatic coordinates of the dyed fabrics
Sample L* a* b* C* h DL* E = √L2 + C2
A1 46.64 4.49 −25.54 25.94 279.98 − 53.37
A2 47.84 4.35 −25.54 25.91 279.66 1.21 54.41
A3 48.79 4.02 −24.95 25.27 279.15 2.15 54.95
B1 48.46 4.16 −24.93 25.28 279.47 1.82 54.66
B2 49.15 4.04 −24.72 25.05 279.28 2.51 55.17
B3 49.74 4.08 −24.68 25.01 279.38 3.10 55.67
C1 49.83 4.03 −24.86 25.19 279.20 3.19 55.84
C2 50.21 3.99 −24.47 24.80 279.26 3.58 56.00

Differences in lightness with respect to sample A1 range from 1.21 to 3.58 units and are unacceptable for industrial purposes. The total color E of the sample varies from 53.37 to 56.00. At an industrial level, differences in color between samples ΔE < 1 are accepted. Table 4 classifies the filaments according to their total color value E and enables us to identify three groups of four filaments each, showing an acceptable level of differences in color (ΔE < 1). Despite stabilization, significant differences in color absorption between sample A1 and the other filaments remain, including differences between the groups (see Table 4). Table 4.
Homogeneous color groups with color differences ΔE < 1

Differences in dye absorption should be explained by differences in microstructure. Stabilization considerably increases crystallinity XDSC (between 60 and 100%), and the wet thermal treatment, at which the stabilized filaments are subjected to during dyeing, greatly enhances the crystallinity of the substrates, promoting the readjustment of the segments of the polymer chains trapped between crystallites to give further secondary crystallization.18 Figures 2 and 3 show the marked increase in crystallinity as observed by X-ray. Figure 2.
Increase in crystallinity of substrate by stabilization and dyeing.
Figure 3.
WAXS diffractogram of textured, fixed and dyed substrates.

The wide angle X-ray (WAXS) profile of the PLA textured samples with very high content of amorphous phase corresponds to that of an amorphous and oriented substrate. The WAXS profile of the stabilized substrate exhibits the profile of an α′ form induced when an amorphous phase is drawn at 100℃. The dyed substrate points out the profile of an α form produced by isothermal crystallization at the dyeing conditions. Both the α′ and the α form are orthorhombic being the former a distorted variant of the latter as pointed out by different authors.19,20

After stabilization, differences in crystallinity XDSC and orientation SV between substrates (CV ≈ 2.5%) are within the experimental error of these techniques. It is therefore expected that iodine sorption and differential solubility are more accurate than crystallinity and orientation in detecting the small differences in microstructure. The results of iodine sorption and differential solubility are given in Table 5. Table 5.
Iodine sorption and differential solubility results
Ref Iodine sorption (mg/g) Differential solubility (%)
35℃ 40℃ 42.5℃ 45℃ 50℃ 35℃ 40℃
A1 21.8 73.1 94.0 119.2 84.5 21.5 40.5
A2 13.7 40.2 66.4 102.9 75.6 21.8 39.5
A3 15.1 48.4 76.2 95.7 76.8 20.9 37.4
B1 10.4 34.2 60.0 96.0 74.3 19.3 33.6
B2 11.4 33.6 56.5 87.0 75.7 19.7 34.5
B3 12.9 38.6 67.6 92.4 72.9 20.5 35.1
C1 26.0 76.4 96.3 106.7 80.2 23.6 40.4
C2 15.4 42.7 66.9 93.0 74.3 21.2 37.1
Mean 15.8 48.4 73.0 99.1 76.8 20.4 37.3
SD ±5.4 ±16.9 ±14.9 ±10.2 ±3.8 ±1.6 ±2.7
CV (%) 33.9 35.0 20.4 10.3 5.0 8.0 7.3

Iodine sorption increases with test temperature up to a maximum and then decreases. The behavior is similar to that observed in polyester and polyamide fibers.4–9 On the other hand, as expected, differential solubility increases when test temperature rises.

The results show that neither iodine sorption nor differential solubility is related to previous texturing conditions or to the dyeing behavior. In fact, iodine sorption and differential solubility (both at 40℃) are strongly correlated with crystallinity of the stabilized substrates (Figures 3–5). A good linear correlation between iodine sorption and crystallinity (r = −0.934) is observed. Crystallinity growth reduces the possibility for iodine to enter the fiber. Figure 4.
Iodine sorption as a function of crystallinity.
Figure 5.
Differential solubility as a function of crystallinity.

Differential solubility also decreases when crystallinity increases (r = −0.854). As a result of this increase, the fiber becomes more compact. It is expected that iodine sorption and the solvent/non-solvent mixture penetrate the fiber in the amorphous phase. The accessibility of iodine and the solvent/non-solvent mixture in the fiber is directly related to the mobility of the amorphous phase that is measured by the maximum phase lag temperature yielded by TMA. This temperature is a good estimator of the glass transition21 and reflects the mobility of the amorphous phase. The glass transition region can be shifted to higher temperatures by suitable thermal or mechanical treatment of the sample22 like stabilization.

sec.title: Factorial analysis
sec.p: In order to point out the existence of some independent factors that could account for the differences in crystallinity XDSC, sonic velocity SV and maximum phase lag temperature Tϕ results were analyzed by factorial analysis.23 After normalizing the variables, the factorial analysis yields two independent (orthogonal) factors that account for the maximum variability within textured and within stabilized filaments. Factor 1 for both textured and stabilized filaments is mainly dependent on SV and Tϕ although it includes a small contribution from XDSC, and Factor 2 is dominated by XDSC although it includes small influences from SV and Tϕ. The linear transformation functions of the normalized values of sonic velocity SV*, maximum phase lag temperature Tϕ* and crystallinity measured by DSC XDSC* to get the orthogonal factors given by factorial analysis are the following

Textured filaments
Factor 1 (textured) = 0.88SV* + 0.88Tϕ* + 0.44 XDSC* (explained variability 88.80%)
Factor 2 (textured) = 0.44SV* + 0.44Tϕ* +0.90XDSC* (explained variability 8.84%)
Remaining unexplained variability: 2.36%

Stabilized filaments
Factor 1 (stabilized) = 0.95SV* + 0.95Tϕ* + 0.08 XDSC* (explained variability 62.57%)
Factor 2 (stabilized) = 0.10SV* + 0.06Tϕ* + 1.00 XDSC* (explained variability 31.58%)
Remaining unexplained variability: 5.85%

With regards to the contribution of XDSC*, SV* and Tϕ* to the factors, Factor 1 mainly picks up the influence of the orientation and, Factor 2, that of the crystallinity. A scatter plot of the textured and the stabilized filaments according to the results of the factorial analysis is given in Figure 6. Figure 6.
Scatter plot of the textured and stabilized PLA multifilaments according to the factors given by the factorial analysis applied to sonic velocity SV, maximum phase lag temperature Tϕ and crystallinity XDSC given by DSC.

The scatter plot of the textured filaments draws a logical evolution according to the texturing conditions: When both the draw ratio and texturing temperature are higher, the orientation and the crystallinity of the filaments are higher. Filaments C1 and C2 appear to be slightly shifted to higher orientation values probably due to their higher draw ratio (1:1.4).

Stabilization causes an increase in orientation and crystallinity but in different ways. The scatter plot of the stabilized filaments identifies three different groups of filaments according to their crystallinity and orientation:
Less oriented filaments (A1, A3, B3, B1): SV < 2.35 km/s, Tϕ ≤ 72.2℃. Crystallinity increase vs. orientation growth: 0.73.
More oriented / less crystalline filaments (C1, C2): SV > 2.35 km/s, Tϕ ≥ 72.3℃, XDSC < 51%. Crystallinity increase vs. orientation growth: -31.
More oriented / more crystalline filaments (A2, B2): SV > 2.35 km/s, Tϕ ≥ 72.3℃, XDSC > 51%. Crystallinity increase vs. orientation growth: 0.48.

The crystallinity increase vs. orientation growth of the less oriented filaments exceeds that of the more oriented/more crystalline group, while in the more oriented/less crystalline group differences in crystallinity are not related to differences in orientation.

sec.title: Physicochemical tests and accessibility of the amorphous phase
sec.p:
As for the relationship between differential solubility and the accessibility of the amorphous phase, which decreases when the maximum phase lag temperature increases, Figure 7 shows the same three groups depicted in Figure 6. The differential solubility of the less oriented filaments decreases when Tϕ increases. The decrease seems to reflect the increase in orientation and crystallinity of the filaments. Figure 7.
Differential solubility of PLA stabilized multifilaments as a function of the maximum phase lag temperature.
With regards to the more oriented/less crystalline group, a very short increase in Tϕ implies a high decrease in differential solubility linked to the increase in crystallinity of the filament.

The increase in Tϕ in the more oriented/more crystalline filaments implies a high decrease in the differential solubility of the filaments linked to the increase in both orientation and crystallinity of the filaments.

With regards to the relationship between iodine sorption and Tϕ, the three groups of Figure 6 also appear. The iodine sorption of the less oriented filaments decreases with Tϕ. The decrease follows the same tendency of the differential solubility, linked to the increase in orientation and crystallinity of the filaments.
When the more oriented/less crystalline group is considered, a short increase in Tϕ implies a very high decrease in iodine sorption linked to the increase in crystallinity of the filaments.
The increase in Tϕ in the third group of more oriented/more crystalline filaments is linked to a very small decrease in iodine sorption.

Differential solubility and iodine sorption appear to be related with the accessibility of the amorphous phase measured by the maximum phase lag temperature. These techniques enabled us to clearly identify microstructural differences between stabilized filaments included in the first group of “less oriented” filaments (SV < 2.35 km/s, Tϕ ≤ 72.2℃).

With regards to the “highly oriented” filaments (SV > 2.35 km/s, Tϕ ≥ 72.3℃), the iodine sorption is highly sensitive to differences in crystallinity when the “less crystalline” filaments (XDSC < 51%) are analyzed, while the differential solubility is highly sensitive to differences in crystallinity when the “more crystalline” filaments (XDSC > 51%) are considered.

Summarizing, if highly oriented filaments differ in both crystallinity and orientation, although differences in Tϕ are relevant, the differential solubility technique is more useful than iodine sorption to identify possible differences in microstructure between the stabilized filaments.

sec.title: Microstructure and color differences in stabilized false-twist textured filaments
sec.p: In order to identify the microstructural parameters with the greatest influence on total color value E of the stabilized false-twist textured PLA filaments, a multiple regression analysis between E (Table 3) and crystallinity, sonic velocity, maximum phase lag temperature (Table 2), iodine sorption and differential solubility at 40℃ (Table 5) was performed. To select “the best” regression equation, the forward regression procedure24 was applied and the most significant equation was as follows (2)E=-59.77+1.95Tϕ-11.0 9SV where E is the total color value, Tϕ is the maximum phase lag temperature and SV is the sonic velocity of the samples. The determination coefficient of the equation is R2 = 81.63%; the most important contribution being that of the maximum phase lag temperature (63.33%) followed by that of the sonic velocity (18.30%).

The accessibility of the amorphous phase decreases with the maximum phase lag temperature that mainly depends on false-twist draw ratio (r = 0.76). When the texturing draw ratio is higher, the accessibility of the amorphous phase is lower. The additional contribution of the sonic velocity on the total color value points out the relevant influence of the orientation on the total color value of the samples. Figure 9 plots the relationship between the observed total color value E and the predicted total color value using equation 2 (the tolerance limit for color differences ΔE < 1 is included), and Table 4 makes clear the effect of texturing variables on the color differences between samples. Figure 8.
Iodine sorption of the stabilized PLA multifilaments as a function of maximum phase lag temperature.
Figure 9.
Relationship between observed and predicted total color value E using the maximum phase lag temperature and the sonic velocity of the samples.

sec.title: Conclusions
sec.p:
With regards to the effect of stabilization on crystallinity, orientation and dyeing behavior of false-twist textured filaments, the following conclusions may be drawn:
Stabilization increases crystallinity and orientation of the textured filaments with the result that the samples are more uniform for both parameters. The differences in the accessibility of the amorphous phase measured by the maximum phase lag temperature remain.
After stabilization the effect of the texturing draw ratio and that of the texturing temperature in dye absorption remain. When the texturing intensity is higher, the dye absorption is lower. Differences in dye absorption can result in unacceptable color value differences ΔE > 1. Despite stabilization, PLA filaments false-twist textured under different conditions can cause dyeing irregularities when mixed in a fabric.
Iodine sorption and differential solubility show a good linear relationship with crystallinity: when the crystallinity is higher, the iodine sorption and the differential solubility are lower. The sonic velocity (orientation) is closely related to the accessibility of the amorphous phase measured by the maximum phase lag temperature. When the orientation is higher, the accessibility of the amorphous phase reached by stabilization is lower.
Although iodine sorption and differential solubility show higher sensitivity than crystallinity and/or orientation in differentiating between substrates, the maximum phase lag temperature and the sonic velocity enabled us to predict the color value E of the stabilized false-twist textured filaments, allowing us to discriminate between acceptable and unacceptable color differences. When the orientation is higher and the accessibility of the amorphous phase is lower, the dye absorption is lower.
The strong relationship between differential solubility and iodine sorption with the maximum phase lag temperature highlights the influence of texturing temperature on filaments textured at the highest draw ratio when compared with other filaments textured under smoother conditions.
When highly oriented highly crystalline filaments are considered, differential solubility seems to be more relevant than iodine sorption in the identification of microstructural differences between samples.

sec.p: This work is part of project MAT2007-66569-C02 financed by the Spanish Ministry of Education and Science in its Materials Program. The authors are indebted to the Spanish Project MAT2010-20324-C02 for funding the analysis of the results and the publication costs.

Also to the BM16-CRG/Consorci Laboratori Llum Sincrotro (LLS) c/o European Synchrotron Radiation Facility (ESRF), Grenoble, France for the facilities provided for the use of the equipment and to the Spanish Science and Technology Ministry and DURSI (Department of Universities, Research and Information Society) for the grant that was received.
